correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in / tags, wrapped in a element.

normalization.p: Where appropriate, spelling and punctuation have been modernised using / tags, wrapped in a element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

Bastards are
borb born . There is a crude appetite a greed a

which moves under the flowers and suddenly glares at us.
Bastards are born in the flesh. Reputations are ruined.

Only the people
themlves themselves pass unseen. They too like the
dramatists remain anonymous.
Yet there is a strange contradiction. If the

wr country
bgentlemen gentlement and their wives must speak in

hyperbole when they write
f of love, they write of possessions
in plain English. No generation had more anxiety to preserve [illeg.]

their physical bodies from decay.
Theyeat They eat prodigously.
They wear clothes that are so heavy they can scarcely move

in them.
Invenory Inventory after inventory records their
furiture furniture ,
their jewels, their horses and carriages. When they die,
heavy marble tombs are raised over them. The outer life

is as
substa tial substantial as cloth of gold and pigs capons hogs
can make it. But the mind that lives in the head, the
heart that hxxx speak only on the Bankside, through the
mouths of the players.
Txmxmxmxmxmxmx
Yet in no age can there have been a deeper gulf

between the artist and
socity society . A young poet dedicates his

sonnets to Mr W. H. Not one of all those highly
eduvated educated
nobles troubles to ask who is this patron? It is not a matter
of interest in court circles. The plays are not discussed.

Lord
Southmapton Southampton and Lord Rutland, Roland White wrote to
Sir Robert Sidney, pass away the time in London, merely in

going to plays
ev y every day" But the attraction of the stage
called forth no comment. The players lived too far from the
court to stir curiosity. They were too much of servants,

too much of minstrels, jugglers
nbear bear
laeders leaders to
be a proper topic for gossip. Thus the early works of

Shakeepare Shakespeare make no ripple in the pool of
sielnce silence .
No one protests that here is an upstart writer who is

for
throwin throwing society into the melting pot. The
grreat great might

be mocked--that was the
anicient ancient privilege of the court

jster jester ; or some scene from history
re encated reenacted . But the censor
was quick to control irreverence. And in fact the dramatist
wasnot destroying society. The indignation that, after the
first silent surprise, that Ibsen for example stirred in
London was partly the rage of those who felt that
